div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. div.head: THE MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
div.p: An important announcement appears in this morning’s telegrams in regard to the Morocco Conference, which, it is to be hoped, will have a reassuring effect on Europe. The Cologne Gazette, which has often been employed to convey important information by the Imperial Government, ridicules the idea of war resulting should the Conference prove abortive, and declares that the status quo will be maintained even if all the debates at Algeciras end in a fiasco. A Renter« telegram from Berlin declares that the article is inspired, and if so, its publica-tion it evidently due to a desire of the Berlin Government to remove the existing very general distrust of German diplomacy. It may be, of course, that there is no ground for pessimism, and that both Count Tattenbach and Herr von Radowitz have received instructions to be oonciliatory ; bat the history of the Moroccan dispute so far does not encourage sanguine anticipations. Until it is known exactly what claims Germany advances, there can be no certainty that the Conference will not fail. One thing, however, is assured, Great Britain is in thorough agreement with the French claims, and throughout the Conference it will be the duty of our representative to support M. Revoil; in the unhappy event of an arrangement not being arrived at, the British Government will still be ready to assist France in whatever way is needful to secure justice. This, we take it is generally understood in Europe and it is now realised that any hopes that have been built on the present change of Administration at home, and a consequent vacillation on of policy, are unfounded. Up to now there has been much talk of conciliation and of the entirely pacific inten-tions of Germany, such amiable assurances having bean freely provided by the German Press. Unfortunately, however, there is nothing to show that the German representatives at the Conference have received instructions of a really conciliatory nature. On the contrary, there has hitherto been no abatement in the insistence of the German inspired Press on the necessity of internationalising' the Moroccan police, excepting that on the Algerian frontier.” That proposal will be resisted by Prance and the Powers which will act with her. These Powers, as we know, are England, Russia, Italy, and, in all probability. 8pain and the United States. Against such a combination Germany will be powerless, and she will have either to submit or to upset the card table by a gesture of impatience which might have the most serious consequences to the world's peace. It would appear, however, from the announcement which the Berlin Government has made through the Cologne Gazette that Germany has decided to submit.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p:
TIME CONCENTRATION MARCH. Owing to the Bairam Holidays, the troops of the Egyptian Army will not be able to join in a field day during the ensuing week. In place of the usual weekly field day the troops of the Army of Occupation will be exercised t> morrow in a Time Concentration March, under the following scheme Abbassia.—M.I., M.M.P., 1st Bn. K.R.R. Corps, with 1 maohiue gun, will parade under orders of the Commandant so as to move off at 8 a.m. They will march t j the Abattoir from which point they will be lei to the Citadel (Inner Square opposite the Officers Mess), by an Intelligence Officer detailed by the General Officer Commanding. The M.M.P. will atop in the Outer Square Kaar-e.-Nil.— 2nd Co, R R 2nd Bn. Royal Instilling Fusiliers, with 8 machine guns, will parade under orders of the Commandant so as to move off at 9 a m., and will be led to the Inner Square. Citadel, as above Citadel.—R G A with 2 15-pr. guns 2nd Bn. Royal Berk-*. Regt., will parade under orders from the Commandant in the Outer Square, Citadel, opposite the Guard Room, at 10 a.m. After the troops have met at the rendezvous they will form into three columns as follows: - let Column (Outer 8quare) to march off at 10 20 am. - R G. A., 2nd Bo Royal Berkshire Regiment under the command of Major R. Percy-Smith. R.G.A., will be led to the second place of rendezvous as above. 2nd Column (Officer's Me Square) to march off at 10.35 a.m.—M.l. 1st Bn , KRR Corps UNDER THE COMMAND OF LT COL CJ MARKAM 1st Bn. KRR Corps, will be led to the 2nd place of rendezvous as above.
The object of the exercise is to concentrate definite place at a definite time.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Paniau idlicea of the Anglo-Egyptian | Hank have been removed to 29 Rue Taitboot. A- S C * Lieut. Napier, A. S. C., ha* been appointed to the Army Service Corps at Cairo in place I of Lieut. Bleucowe, who baa proceeded to | Khartoum. Gordon College Mr. George Urqnbart, bridge contractor. Sudan Government Railways, has undertaken the construction of the west wing of Gord in College at Khartoum at the coat of L.R 12,000 Rifle Meeting. The detachment of the A. S. C. at Alexandria have entered a team for the forthcoming title meeting at Cairo. Taking into consideration the excellent shooting this detachment did last year, they ought to make a record for themselves The Bishop's Visit to Egypt, Bishop Byh. Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem and the East arrives at Port Said and proceed to Cairo on Wednesday next. His Lordship will visit Alexandria from February 17-19 and on Sunday the 18th inst., will officiate at 8t. Mark’s, Alexandria, and All Saint’s, Ramleh. Millionaire Dies at Cairo. Thomas J. Emery, the multi-millionaire of Cincinnati, who has died in Cairo, was on his tenth trip to Africa and his fiftieth trip to Europe. Mr. Emery was a patron of the arts, and noted for his philanthropy. He was notably generous in aid of Booker T. Washington's educational work. Renta at Alexandria. An Arabic contempoary publishes an article advocating the dredging and restoration of the port of Damieta as a panacea for the extortionate increases of rents in Alexandria. The argument is that if Dami-tta was restored to its ancient prosperity the surplus population of Alexandria would be drawn thither, thereby decreasing the demaod for houses here.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS
div.p: LONDON, February 3. The "Standard” says that Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain dined together yesterday evening and discussed the future of the party. During the afternoon Mr. Chamberlain had conferred with the Committee of Liberal Unionists on the same subject, and on Thur - day Mr. Balfour consulted with his most intimate followers. The "Standard” declares that unless Mr. Balfour accepts Mr. Chamberlain’s general tariff policy, his leadership of a united party will be gone for ever. As Mr. Chamberlain will not accept the leadership of a divided party, his followers will then form an independent organisation. The only alternative would be to afford another leader, say, Mr. Walter Lorg, an opportunity of giving party unity. It is not yet decided whether the Liberals will oppose Mr. Balfour’s candidature in the City. (Reuter) LONDON, February 4. The "Observer” states that Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain parted in discord on Friday. The Opposition will therefore be split into two groups. (Reuter)

div.head: Disestablishment in France
Disturbers Punished
div.p: PARIS, February 3. Count de La Rochefoucauld has been sen-tenced to three months’ imprisonment and several others prosecuted for the same offence have received shorter terms. (Reuter) PARIS, February 3. The taking of inventories in the Churches is proceeding without serious disorders. (Reuter

div.head: Death of Lady Grey
div.p: LONDON, February 3. Lady Grey is worse. (Reuter) LONDON, February 4. Lady Grey is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: Austria and Servia- Tariff War Ends
div.p: VIENNA, February 3. The Tariff war between Austria and Servia is at end, Servia having agreed to yield to Austrian pressure, and having abandoned the- Customs’ Union with Bulgaria. (Reuter)

div.head: The Austrian Lloyd- A strike
div.p: TRIESTE, February 4. The strike of the stokers and seamen of the Austrian Lloyd prevents the departure of the steamers. (Reuter

div.head: France and Castro- Will there be war
div.p: WILLEMSTAD, February 4. Passengers from La Guaira report that President Castro is preparing tor war, and that he has given orders to fire on the first French war-ship sighted. He has asserted that he considers the whole French movement to be bluff. (Reuter)

div.head: The Viceroy of Ireland
div.p: DUBLIN, February 3 The Earl and Countess of Aberdeen made their state entry to-day. ( Reuter)

div.head: Italin Cabinet
div.p: ROME, February 4. Mr. Sonnino has received a mandate to form the Cabinet. (Havas

div.head: Gen Linevitch's Successor
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, February 4. It is rumoured that General Grodekow will replace General Linievitch. (Havas

div.head: Football
div.p: LONDON, February 3. (Rugby). Wales beat Scotland by 9 to 8.

div.head: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
div.p:
IMPORTANT STATEMENT.
GERMANY’S IDEAS. ALGECIRAS, Febrnary 3. The Conference has refused to entertain a proposal of the Moorish delegates concerning the increase in the customs dues. The Confer ence will study the possibility of establishing a slight sur tax in the shape of some additional' centimes (Havas BERLIN, February 4. The Koelnishe Zeitung in an inspired artic ridicules the idea of a war resulting from th Morocco Conference at Algericas. It says that if the Conference be a fiasco, the status quo will by maintained. (Reut* ) COLOGNE, February 4. The "Cologne Gazette states that the check in the proceedings of the Algeciras Conference will not lead to war. The status quo ante 1880 will continue.* (Havas)

div.head: The Assouan Ball
div.p: (FROM A CORRESPONDENT). Assouan, January 30. The fancy dress dance held at the Cataract Hotel last night was voted a great success. But in recording any success there are surely one or two minor points of adverse criticism that are always worthy of mention if a report of an event of this kind is to be in any way of the nature of a criticism. This being granted let us take our two minor points and have done with them ! The most unmusical dancer present oould hardly fail to have observed the lamentable lack of time on the part of the band which went far to spoil the whole evening’s enjoy¬ment The instrumentalists appeared to believe that they were giving ns a concert, and that if any of the audience oared to dance to their music they only had themselves to blame ! Our other point is the result of the voting for the best fancy dresses for ladies and gentlemen. Out of many beautiful and excellent costumes, a lady who had the hardihood to blank her face and appear as a Cook’s dragoman before natives and Berberine servants was singled out by the majority of voters as the wearer of the best get-up in the room. It was undoubtedly clever, but rather made one shudder than feel pleased under the circumstances. Still more remarkable was the selection of a most incoc- guous so-called mandarin for the gentleman’s prise. This mandarin wore a Chinaman’s hat that was not a mandarin’s, he wore a clergy¬man’s collar, a mandarin’s coat hired from an Indian for the evening, and shoes that were anything bat those of a Chinaman I ! He also wore a very English face which bore no attempts at a Chinese "make up. Of the ladies we thought that a charming Swiss peasant-girl, the recognised "belle of the ball,” carried off the palm. A Spanish dress and a Moorish dress were also very much ad¬mired. To come to the gentlemen, the clever impersonation of a lady effected by our popu¬lar organist here succeeded in deceiving us all, and was quite the event of the evening. Next to this we admired a very handsome Direotoire costume greatly, the coat we nnderstand is ori ginal. A benevolent looking and rather corpu¬lent tourist with a wonderful umbrella and a still more wonderful insect on his helmet was a very clever get-up, but it proved too much for the wearer who returned to his normal self after a couple of dance. A costume from Veronique, and an ordinary native dress are worthy of note, this last being very effec¬tive as the wearer appeared to have the graceful, swinging step of the Arab which carried off his black, flowing "galabiya” very well. In a word, with the exception of the music, a most enjoyable evening was spent and the management are to be congratulated on the result of the evening.

div.head: Band Performance
div.p: By kind permission of Lt. Col. R. C. C. Cox commanding and officers of the 2nd Battn. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the band will perform the following selection of music at the Gymkhana, to be held at Mena House Hotel to-morrow afternoon, Feb. 6th. March—Hands across the Sea—Sousa, Morceau—La Lettre de Manon—Gillet. Seleotion—Faust—Gounod. Valse—Soldaten Lieder—Gung’l. American Two-Step—Mumblin' Moss—Thurban. Song—The Children’s Home—Cowen. Seleotion—A Country Girl—Caryll and Monokton. Indian Charaoteristique—Navajo—Van Alstyne. Regimental March.—Khedivial Anthem. God Save the King. R, WATSON RAMSAY, Bandmaster.

div.head: Walker and Meimarachi
div.p: 125,000 6 1/2 pep cent. Cumulative Preference Shares of £1 each, ranking in priority to the Ordinary Shares both as to Capital and Dividend, and 275,000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each. Issue of 100,000 ORDINARY SHARES of £1 each at par payable 2/-. upon Application, 3/- upon Allotment, 3/- 28th February. 1906, B/- 31 at Maroh. 1906, B/- 31 at May 1906 Payments in full may be made on allotment, or at any date fixed for the payment of any of the instalments and Shares will carry Dividends upon the amount for the time being paid up. Directors. L. CARTON DE WIART, Cairo-Egypt, Director "Compagnie Immobilize d’Egypte, etc, Chairman. ADOLPHE CATTAOUI, Cairo-Egypt, Banker. MONTAGU SUMMERS, F.Z.S.,F..R..G.S., Cairo-Egypt, Managing Direotor“Egyptian Estates Ltd.” J. E. DROWER, 28, Victoria Street, London, S. W. Surveyor. W. A. LUNING, 65, London Wall, London E. C. Merchant. Managing Director. C. G. MEIMARACHI, Cairo, Egypt, Merchant. General Manager. GEORGE WALKER. Secretary in Egypt. C. SENDER HOCHSTRASSER. Bankers. THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED, London, Cairo, and Alexandria. Auditors. RUSSELL, KERR A WYATT, Chartered Accountants, Moorgate Court,London E.C., Cairo and Alexandria. Secretary and Registered Offices. H. P. HOOD, 66, London Wall, London, E.C. Branch Offices. 71, Mosley Street, Manchester. | 94, Rue Lafayette, Paris, PROSPECTUS. This company was formed in December, 1897, for the purpose of acquiring the business of Messrs. Walker and Co., of Cairo, as from the 1st May, 1897, and that of Messrs. C. G. Meimarachi and Co., Cairo, as from 1st July 1897. The original capital of the Company WAS £250,000, divided into 25,000 6 1/2 per cent. Preference Shares of £5 each, and 25,000 Ordinary Shares of £6 each, of which latter only

15,000 Shares were issued. increasing £1 each, Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., is now the moat important kind in Egypt as Army Contractors, Wine and Spirit Merchants, Provision Dealers, Drapers, Milliners, and Silk and General Merchants, having important Agencies and Sob Agencies a large number of the principal leading English, French, German, Italian, and Austrian manufacturing houses doing business in Egypt. The financial prosperity of Egypt during the last few years has improved beyond all anticipation, and its continuance is regarded as an established fact. Of recent years the agriculture of the country has developed, railways have been completed, districts hitherto inaccessible to trade have been opened op, and insignificant villages in a few years have developed into prosperous and thriving towns, with the resalt that the purchasing power of the ever increasing population has led to a growing demand for European manufactures and commodities. Owiog to the extensive business experience and influence of its Executive in Egypt, the Company is in a position to continue to command an increasing volume in every department of native and European trade. Owing to the recent development in trade in Egypt, the Company’s premises were found to be inadequate to cope with the growth of its business. During the last few years the centre of the trade of Cairo has changed, and what was convenient at the time of the forma¬tion of the Company has recently become unsuited to its customers. The Directors, realising the necessity for meeting these altered conditions, have purchased certain land situate in the fashionable Ismailieh quarter of Cairo. The purchase price of the property is L.E. 72,247.800 and the report of Mr. Henry Hinks (Messrs. Barclay Hinks and Co. Cairo) a member of the Suveyors Institution, London dated the 16th of January 1906, in respect to its value when acquired and present value is as follows. . ‘‘I have an inspection of the property lately purchased by you at the junction of Charia El Manakh and Charia El Madabegh in the Ismailieh quarter of Cairo at the price of LB. 72,247. “The property is of an area of 4816.5 square metres, of a rectangular shape and through its central position in the European business and residential quarter, it undoubtedly provides one of the finest and most suitable sites in Cairo for the ereotion of yoor new buildings. .“In my opinion the present value of this property is ninety six thousand, three hundred and thirty pounds Egyptian (L.E. 96330,) or £20 per square metre. still amount greatly exceeds, your purchase price; the value of land in this quarter is still rising, and a farther increase may be expected should the new Bourse be erected, as is intended, on a site in the immediate vicinity." .. The Directors have arranged with Nungovich Bey for placing £100,000 5 per, cent Mortgage Debentures and the amount produced from these Debentures and the present issue (which has already been guaranteed by Nungovich Bey) will provide the necessary funds for the purchase of the land and the erection of suitable buildings thereon, in addition to providing further working capital for the Company. No deferred Shares have been issued, and after payment of the Preference Dividend amounting to £8,125 per annum, provision for Interest on Debentures reserve, depreciation, etc., the balance of profit is available for dividend to the holders of ordinary Shares. Perusal of the following returns based upon the Company’s published accounts and Balance Sheets, duly certified by Messrs. W. B. Peat and Co., Chartered Accountants, of London, serve to show the soundness and progressive nature of the Company’s trading since.its incorporation to the date of the last published Balance Sheet to 80th April, 1905, and there is every reason to anticipate even more satisfactory progress in the future, The Net Profits of Trading after deducting cost of management in Egypt have been as follows : -

The total amount written off Goodwill etc., has amounted to £30,499.3. 8. The Reserve Fund amounts to £5f45l. 8, 10. The dividends distributed on the ordinary shares during the past three years have been as follows : For the 12 months ending 80th April, 1903, at the rate of 8 per cent. £ 2,250. 0.0. i» «» 60th April, 1904, •• 4 per oent £ 3,000.0.0« •i >t 80th April, 1905, .. 6 per oent. £ 3.750.0.0, At the 80th April, 1905, the amount oarried forward was £ 3,339. 0. 9. A Contract dated the 18th of January 1906 has been entered into between the Company and GeoTge Nungovich Bey, whereby tbe latter has agreed to subscribe (or ^ A ^ bole or soon pert of the promt issne of 100,000

Ordinwy Share. as have not been applied for within a consideration of which the Company has agreed to pay him by way of commission the sum of fio.ooo. By this contract an earlier contract between the same parties dated the 20th of May 1905 and another contract in the form of a letter from G. Nungoyioh Bey to the Company dated the 19th of September 1905 were rescinded. . A Contract dated the 13th of January 1906 has been entered into between the Company and George Nu govich Bey, whereby the Utter, in consideration of hi, subscribing for £1(0 000 5 per cant. Mortgage Debentures at 90 per cent., redeemable at parat the expiration of 60 years or earlier on six months notice by the Company, was panted an option to subscribe at par for the balance of the Company s unissued shares for The ^Slowing contract relate to the purchase by the Company of the before mention- '“A contract dated the 13th of November 1905 between the Egyptian Estates Limited of the one part and Constantin George Memarachi of Cairo of the other part by which the latter purchased the same for L B. 72,247.800. A contract dated the 13th of January 1906 between the said Constantin George Meimarachi of the first part, the Egyptian Estates Limited of the second part and the Company of the third part by which Mr. Meimaraohi made over to the Company all his rights under the last mentioned contract for the price therein stated. application from soon shareholder will receive a preference other applicants The present issue having been guaranteed, as above mentioned the Directors will only go to alotment on the whole of the issue. 0 the 16th of December, 1897, 25.000 preference shares of £5 each were offered for subscription, and the whole of these shares were allotted and have been paid op in full On the formation of the Company 15,000 ordinary shares of £5 each were issued as fully paid as the purchase consideration for the two businesses above mentioned. Conies of the above contracts, the Memorandum and Articles of Association, and the Balance Sheets, containing the certificates of Messrs. W. B. Peat and Co., can be inspected by intending subscribers during the time the lists are open, at the offices of the Company London. Application will be made in due course for a settlement and official quotation on the London Stock Exchange. Application for shares must be made on the accompanying form and forwarded to the Company’s bankers, together with a remittance for the amount of the deposit. Share Warrants to Bearer in denominations of 5, 25 and 50 shares will be issued in respect of fully Paid Shares to any shareholders desiring same free of cost. If no allotment be made the deposit will be returned in full, and if only a portion of the amount applied for be allotted the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the payment due on allotment. Failure to pay any of the instalments or calls at due date will render all previous payments liable to forfeiture. The prospectuses and forms of application may be obtained from the Company’s Bankers, and at the offices of the Company in London, Paris, Manchester and Egypt.
Various sub-under writing Contracts have been entered into by George, Nungovich, Bey Some of the present Shareholders having represented to the Directors that they were

div.head: CORRESPONDENCE- LES ELECTIONS
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de 1’“Egyptian Gazette.’ Voua avez déjà, lors des dernières élections insisté sur la défectuosité de la loi électorale mun c'pale d’Alexandrie Les électeurs dont le nornhie est excessivement restreint sont porïr la plupart des gens d’affaires qui n’ont pas le loisir de s’occuper des questions municipales ou des dé œovrés, qui s’en désintéressent oom- p’ètement. Le votes des uns et des autres sont acquis d’avance non pas au bon candidat, hon¬nête et intelligent, mais au plus plat, au pins incapable, au plus véreux. Le droit pour le commerce d’élire la moitié des conseillers est également un abus incompréhensible : ne dirait- on pas qn’Alexandrie est une simple faotorerie du Congo ou de la Côte d’ivoire ? Tant que notre ville sera soumise à la loi électorale existante, les personnalités honoia blés et capables seront tenues à l’écart affaires municipales au grand profit des ar rivistes et des tripoteurs. A cet égard le passé est une leçon : les membres actuels du oonseil munioipal ne se font remarquer ni par leur lèle, ni par leurs aptitudes, ni par Jour déair de servir les intérêts du public. Parmi ceux qui sortent à la fin de ce mois, il en est qui n’ont jamais ouvert la bouche,d’autres qui n’ont assisté qu’à quelques rares séances, d’autres enfin qui n’ont fait un peu de bruit que pour leurs intérêts personnels ou leur gloriole. Ceux qui vont les remplacer seront-ils meil leurs 7 Auoun personnage sérieux ne s’est en-core mis sur les rangs et oelà se conçoit : est difficile, pour ne pas dire impossible, à un bon o^ndidat de se faire élire, sans s’abaisser à des procédés peu recommandables. Dans ces conditions la., ville d’Alexandrie peut attendre longtemps ses réformes : surveil lance des marchés, contrô'e des poids et me sures, assainissement public, baisse des loyers, service du balayage et de l’arrosage, canalisa¬tion des rues. Tout cela ne vieudra pas desitô Nos édiles présents et futurs ont d’autres sou¬cis : ÜB* ont acheté des terrains dans un empla cernent désert et ils s’occupent d’y faire passer une rue ou mieux encore une ligne de tram way ; ils ont pris des aotions d’une sooiété et ils s’efforcent de faire accorder une concession à cette Eooiété, etc. etc. Pour cela il n’y besoin ni de disoours, ni d’études, ni de dévoue¬ment : il suffit de voter : C’est le "struggle for life” au palais munioipal. Le jour où les Alexandrins voudront ore gestion loyale et désintéressée ils devront faire modifier la loi électorale ou reoverser la Muni-cipalité. ’ A.G.

div.head: SUCRERIES ET RAFFINERIE D’EGYPTE
div.p: Il ressort de l’état comparé des cannes tra-vaillée au 29 janvier 1906, par les Suoreries, que 193 journées de travail dans les usines de Matai, Abon Eonrgas, Ermant, Mat ma, Nag- Hamadi, Cheikh Fadl, ont permis de travailler 288,754 tonnes de cannes, soit une moyenne générale de 7,733 par jour. Or l’exeroice de 194 a donné 258,250 tonnes pendant 216 journées de travail, soit nne moyenne de 7,7 4 tonnes par jour. Encore faut-il ajouterque dans cette période de 1905-1906, l’usine de Bibeh n’a pas fonctionné. Ainsi avec 23 journées de travail en moins et 1 usine arrêtée, le total de la canne travaillée n’a pas baissé. Cela prouve que la nouvelle administration peut réaliser des économies sensibles, sans prë¥ judioe pour la production. Par ordonnance de jeudi, rendue par le pré-sident Tuck, M. John Home, directeur de 1A National Bank of Eeypt, a éfé nommé contrôleur des Sucreries ef lUffinerie d’E/ypte en rempla cernent de Sir Elwin Palmer, décédé.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA "ANTAR.”
div.p: Ün nombreux publio assistait samedi soir à la première représentation de cette tragédie qui a, comme l’on sait, obtenu un grand succès au Caire. Le sujet, emprunté à la légende arabe, ne se prêtait guère à nne œuvre théâtrale M. Chekri Ganem a cependant réussi à en faire ni e bonne adaptation. La figure du héros-poète est fort bien des-sinée. Les personnages conservent jusqu’au bont de la pièce leur caractère national ; leur language, plein de métaphores empruntées au style du temps, est empreint d’une vive imagi¬nation orientale. Un des prinoipaux mérites de l’auteur est, en effet, d’avoir reproduit en de beaux vers fran¬çais toute la saveur de la littérature arabe. Le dia'ogne d amour avec Abla au 4me acte est l’un des plus beaux passages de l'œuvre. L auditoire, composé en grande partie de syriens, a fait une véritable fête à l’auteur, Chékri Gmem, qui ada se présenter plusieurs fois sur la scène.

div.head: DECES
div.p: Noos avons le regret d’annoDcer la mort de MADAME CATHERINE TREHAKI, dé Hée hier an Caire. 1,8 cortège funèbre partira aujourd'hui de la Gare dn Caire à 3 heures p.m. précises pour se rendre directement au cimetière. Nous adressons à la famille éplorée nos senti méats sincères de condoléance.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny- NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Caire, 8 février. Le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié hier à Londres à 90 1/2. L’Unifiée a monté de 1/4 à 105. La National Bank est renseignée en nou¬velle hausse de 3/8 à 27 3/8, la Daira de 1/4 à 17 5/8. etl’Agrioole, inchangée, à 9 8/4. A Paris, l’aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien a haussé de 8 francs à 808. La Banque d’Athènes a réactionné de 2 francs à 136. * * * Notre marché des valeurs a été, ce matin encore, assez animé, avec tendanoe ferme an début. Après la hausse exceptionnelle des deux dernières séanoes, notamment sur la National Bank, on ponvait, à bon droit, s’attendre à nne réotion très prononcée. Elle ne s’est pourtant guère produite, ce qui tend à montrer que le mouvement ascensionnel s’accentuera aprèB un recnl forcé. La National Bank a ouvert à 27 7/16 pour olôtnrer à 3/* 6. L’Agricole a débnté à 9 29/32 pour finir à 13/16. Bon mouvement snr le Comptoir Financier, q i a atteint 4 15/16 et surtout sur le Wardan rEitate, qui a encore gagné, à 7 1/8, une 1/2 livre sur le oours de la veille. A ce prix il y avait enoore acheteurs, indice qne la hausse est appelée à s’accentuer. L’action Crédit Fonoier a olôturé entre 807- 808 en bonne tendanoe. Les obligations à lots 18k6 ont remonté à 335 ; les nouvelles restent à 274-275. L’Improvements Corporation s’est inscrite à 4 13/16. Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovioh ont avancé à 13 3/4-13/16. Les Baehler se maintiennent fermes à 4 1/4 et l’on pressent an très proobe mouvement sur œ titre. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Cotton Mills o it été très recherchés et ont atteint 6 sh. 3. O i prévoit oaoours bien plus élevé, d’ailleurs jastifié par les raisons que nous avons exoo*ées dans notre Circulaire du 13 Janvier dernier. Les Sait ont olôturé à 23 sh. vendeurs. Les Markets ont fait 25 sh. 6. » • • Nous extrayons d’une lettre de Londres, en iate du 27 janvier, le passage suivant relatif à la situation monétaire : "Malgré les nouvelles favorables de Berlin de New-York et d’ailleurs, la Banque d’Angle-terre oontinae à renforcer sa situation en ac-caparant tout le disponible qu’elle peut trouver snr le marohé. Il en résnlte que le loyer de l’argent reste ioi très tenda. Il faut payer plus de 4 % pour les prêta au joar le jour, au-de’à de 3 3/4 pnnr lu oonrt terme et le t*nx de l’escompte libre reste entre 3 3/4 et 3 7/8. Le numéraire est toujours assez abondant, mais pour en obtenir il faut y mettre le pr x. On oroit que même si la Banque oesse d’agir snr le marché, oelui-oi ne retrouvera pas facilement nne aisance prononcée à cause de l’activité des affaires." I ! Nous avons annoncé que l’assemblée géné-rale du Crédit Fonoier Egyptien a aoprouvé le* comptes de l’exeroioa clos le 31 Octobre 1905 et décidé la distribntioa d’un dividende de 15 franos par aotion. Ce dividende sera payé, à partir du 20 oou- rant, sur la présentation du ooupon N* 26, aux anciennes aotions Nos 1 à 200,000 seulement, les actions nouvelles. Nos 200.001 à 400.00D, ayant été émises avec jouissance du 1er No-vembre 1905. Le dividende de 171 franos par part de fon-dateur (on de Frs. 17,10 par dixième de part) sera également payé à partir du 20 oourant snr présentation du coupon N° 9.

div.head: The Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company. Caire AVIS
div.p: M.M. les Actionnaires sont informés qne le dividende de l’exeroioe éoonlé est payable à partir du 5 Février, au siège de la Société, à raison de : P.T. 85.—par action de Capital P.T. 35. par Part de Dividende. Les titres provisoires actuels n’étant pas de coupons devront être pré-entés au janvier de la Sooiété pour ê«ve frappés d’une de estampille ooi ftatant le paiement.

div.head: Société Anonyme des Eaux du Caire- Avis
div.p: Il est porté à la connaissance du publio que le Conseil d’Administration de la Sooiété a dé¬cidé de réduire de 22 % le prix de l’eau fournie aux Bornes-fontaines publiques. En oooséquenoe, à partir du 1er Janvier 1906 on pourra obtenir l'eau aux dites fontai nés à raison de P T. 3 (trois piastres tarif) le mètre oube au lieu de P.T. 3,857 payées jus qu’ioi. Cette réduction de prix ayant étédéoidée par la Sooiété dans le seul bot d’en faire pn fiter les habitants de la Ville, le pablio est prié de veiller à œ que la dire réduction lui soit faite par les sakas qui lui Garnissent l’eau, afin de ne pas laisser oes derniers profiter du rabais qui n’a été oonsenti qu’en faveur du publia La vente d’eaa au détail aux Bornes-fontai nés, s’établit donc comme soit : Le tonneau de 660 kilos de jauge 20 millièmes Laguerbede 66 „ „ 2 „ L’estagnon de 22 „ „ 3/4 „ et pour toute qnantité dépassant la jauge ci de*8us, ohaque 4 kilos seront comptés à 1/8 de millièmes. Le Caire, le 19 Déoembre 1905. L° Direotenr 26974-30A-18 ASTLBYP. FRIEHD

div.head: Société Generale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d’Egypte - SIEGS SOCIAL AU CAIRE.
div.p: M.M. les Actionnaires sont oonv'-qnés en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire et Extraordi-naire pour le Jeudi 1er Mars 1906, à 4 heures de re’evée, au Sièce Social, au Caire. ORDRE DU JOUR : RAPPORT DU CONSEIL. — Bilan an 31 Ootobre 1905.—Exposé de la situation.—Mesures à prendre eu suite du Conoordat proposé par le Conseil en vertu des pouvoirs donnés par i T Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire du 25
